before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"6goeb","text":"For microbial samples, sanitize bench top surfaces with 70% ethanol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"3est3","text":"Photorepair light exposures are performed on microorganism samples following UV light exposure (i.e. UV disinfection) to determine microorganism regrowth and repair kinetics. Photorepair is a light-dependent, enzyme mediated DNA repair process in bacteria that may reverse UV-induced DNA damage and decrease UV disinfection efficacy. Previously, photorepair kinetics were determined on a time-basis (i.e. exposure times). However, time-based photorepair determinations are not standardized. A photorepair fluence response protocol was developed here according to a standardized protocol proposed by Bohrerova and Linden (2007). If you cite your use of this protocol, you should also cite the relevant original literature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

references.title: Ultraviolet disinfection of wastewater: Effect of dose on subsequent photoreactivation
references.authors: Karl G. Lindenauer, Jeannie L. Darby

references.title: Modelling of reactivation after UV disinfection: Effect of UV-C dose on subsequent photoreactivation and dark repair
references.authors: E. Nebot Sanz, I. Salcedo Davila, J.A. Andrade Balao, J.M Quiroga Alonso

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a6r1f","text":"The photorepair fluence response protocol is based on Bohrerova and Linden (2007).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4h8l0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"29bp1","text":"To perform the photorepair fluence response experiment, you will first need to perform a UV fluence response experiment after the references below. Photorepair experiments and sample handling must be performed in a dark environment. Minimal red light may be used for visibility. This protocol assumes that the user has already performed the UV fluence response experiment. The Polychromatic Fluence (UV Dose) Response Protocol, linked below, can be used for performing the UV exposures.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eu60u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9pvp3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9iue","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"32saa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98ogb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Zuzana Bohrerova, Karl G. that \"UV dose\" and \"UV fluence\" are interchangeable terms in quasi-collimated beam experiments.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1pbba","text":"UV Irradiation: Perform the UV fluence response experiment to prepare the UV irradiated samples for the photorepair fluence response experiment. Experiments must be performed in a dark environment with minimal red light for visibility.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eoq09","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rgbc","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1cter","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ckqps","text":"After UV irradiation: Immediately remove sample from UV exposure. Keep samples in the dark and covered. Perform sample handling and plating in the dark with only red light for visibility. Take sample for microorganism enumeration and molecular analyses. Dilute samples and plate. Set aside samples for molecular analysis and store at -80Â°C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3sljq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ql3a","text":"Transfer the desired of the irradiated sample for photorepair and the remaining sample for dark repair into two identical, sterile Petri dishes (60 mm dishes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fcdsq","text":"Use a pre-determined sample volume for the UV exposure that will permit you to split the sample into two equal volumes and to collect the desired number of samples at pre-determined time intervals.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"45dvo","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fl3tv","text":"Experimental decision making will determine how much sample to perform the UV fluence response exposure with...","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"77o93","text":"How many intervals to collect for photorepair exposures? (e.g. after 15, 30, 60, 120 minutes)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"19sed","text":"For immediate culturing, an example volume to collect: 0.1 mL for enumeration","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1m6vp","text":"For later extraction and molecular analyses, some example volumes to collect: 0.5 mL for nucleic acid analysis, 1 mL for protein analysis, 1.5 mL for both","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9idv4","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8vdef","text":"The volume at the start of the photorepair and dark repair incubations should be sufficient to permit sampling from all the determined sampling intervals.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dmhb1","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"trpq","text":"Sampling: After each time interval, remove the pre-determined sampling volume from the photorepair and dark repair samples. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4g78","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dipqs","text":"Handling: Transfer samples to empty, sterile microcentrifuge tubes. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8832n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dppnl","text":"Dilute and plate organisms immediately: Perform serial dilutions with 1X PBS of samples and plate. Incubate plates under the desired growing conditions for the microorganism. Incubation times will vary per microorganism.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"49qof","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"39pg2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e3ep5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":19,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"8h4i6","text":"Sample Preservation: Save samples for later molecular analyses at -80Â°C. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eu7nf","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":3,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"e3v2e","text":"Tip: Keep samples organized by UV source, UV dose, and time interval. Maintain a record of what samples have been collected and where they are stored.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eu7jq","text":"Before performing the photorepair fluence response experiment, set up the photorepair fluence response experiment apparatus. A light source emitting the desired photorepair light (minimum 300-500 nm emission spectrum) should be suspended above a magnetic stirrer and dish containing the sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"85p2u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cf2t","text":"Warm up the photorepair light source (e.g. 30 minutes before performing exposures).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6pqjt","text":"Start up spectroradiometer and acquisition software. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"acmof","text":"If your spectroradiometer has not been set up to obtain spectral irradiance measurements, set it up, load calibration data (if necessary), and obtain background reading as part of the set up.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3kt0","text":"Obtain spectra irradiance measurements at the surface of the water sample (Figure 1).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3du20","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jmaj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"54anp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"vmp8","text":"The spectroradiometer should be maintained at a perpendicular angle to the light source.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"979q8","text":"Optional if users account for the height adjustment and spectra measurements at different heights: After the experiment, calculate the photorepair fluence for each time interval. Use the irradiance measurements taken at each height for the corresponding time interval to account for the differences in light intensity at different distances from the lamp:   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":97}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":356,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5abli","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpe6t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"","id":397887,"original_name":"PhotorepairFluence_Post-Calculation.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/net9bsif7.xlsx"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3u8td","text":"After obtaining measurements (optional: for each height required), export spectral irradiance data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":30,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"taqv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8h2l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f5tsc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58afm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"pkhj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bl4rd","text":"You can determine the change in sample height after removing sample by using the volume of a cylinder formula for given volume and a known Petri dish diameter.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"c8j2j","text":"Prepare: Determine the number of sample tubes you will need for collecting samples. Label the tubes with sample information, such as: UV source, UV fluence, and time interval, light or dark repair, etc.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6v9m5","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"1886j","text":"Additionally: Prepare 1X PBS dilution tubes ahead of time for dilution and enumeration.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3utg1","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ailc7","text":"Photorepair: Set the distance from the sample surface to the light source. Place the sample for photorepair exposure under the photorepair light at the pre-determined distance. Stir the sample continuously with the magnetic stirrer. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d00c6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e39j9","text":"Dark Repair: Place the dark repair sample on magnetic stirrer in a dark environment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8p8sc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16h8d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"195rb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2feha","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dh24t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fbc1p","text":"Work in a dark environment with minimal red light for visibility to prevent any unwanted photorepair. Check that the red light does not emit any light in the photorepair action spectra (300-500 nm) using a spectroradiometer.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ep1fq","text":"Users may opt to use a quartz cover to prevent evaporation for prolonged exposures.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9mr6l","text":"Optional: To compensate for the change in sample distance from the light source with each subsequent volume withdrawal for sample analysis by calculating the height differential between sampling events, and measuring the light intensity at the center of the dish at the expected level at the start of the experiment to account for the changes in fluence calculation. The change in distance can be calculated using the volume withdrawn and the geometry of the dish (e.g. inner diameter and surface area). The number of measurements will be determined by the number of sampling events that should be pre-determined at the start of the experiment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9en4f","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1r6vq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":275,"id":400714,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"4u7oo\",\"text\":\"Figure 1. Spectral irradiance measurements may be taken at the plane of the water surface level after each sampling event. \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nhknbsif7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nhkkbsif7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nhkmbsif7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nhkjbsif7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2cvjk","text":"Use the Photorepair Fluence spreadsheet to determine the photorepair fluence:  . The contents of each sheet are summarized in Table 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":78,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"593u2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2h7q4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bh6v5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9nj7o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fsj1h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"m7hh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sj5e","text":"Data for the photolyase action spectra was digitized from Payne and Sancar (1990):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6br45","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bjmm2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"","id":397886,"original_name":"PhotorepairFluence_Calculation.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/net8bsif7.xlsx"}},"1":{"type":"tables","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"cellsMeta":{},"colTitles":["",""],"colWidths":["234","356"],"data":[["Sheet Name","Description"],["Fluence Calculations","Primary sheet where fluence calculations are performed. Values must be entered by user for volume, diameter, water path length, distance from light source to sample, weighting factor, and radiometer reading."],["Absorbance","UV-VIS spectrophotometer measurements for the microorganism working stock solution is imported into this sheet."],["Reflection Factor","Pre-calculated reflection factor based on personal communications with Professor Jim Bolton (2016)."],["Weighting","Sheet that accounts for the relative lamp emission of the photorepair lamp, radiometer factor, sample absorbance, Beer Lambert law, photolyase absorbance, and weighting factors to calculate the average intensity."],["Lamp Spectra","Sheet that depicts the lamp spectra, average wavelength, and peak wavelength."],["Irradiance Interpolation","Sheet that performs interpolation function in Excel to output spectral irradiance values for integer wavelengths so that values can be used in the Weighting tab."],["Photolyase Spect Interpolation","Sheet that performs interpolation function in Excel to output photolyase action spectra values for integer wavelengths so that values can be used in the Weighting tab."]],"guid":"B55CB9003D4311EEA5EEFBD4CF947B93","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"30b37","text":"Table 1. Description of contents for the sheets included in PhotorepairFluence_Calculations.xlsx","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mergeCells":{},"printData":[["Sheet Name","Description"],["Fluence Calculations","Primary sheet where fluence calculations are performed. Values must be entered by user for volume, diameter, water path length, distance from light source to sample, weighting factor, and radiometer reading."],["Absorbance","UV-VIS spectrophotometer measurements for the microorganism working stock solution is imported into this sheet."],["Reflection Factor","Pre-calculated reflection factor based on personal communications with Professor Jim Bolton (2016)."],["Weighting","Sheet that accounts for the relative lamp emission of the photorepair lamp, radiometer factor, sample absorbance, Beer Lambert law, photolyase absorbance, and weighting factors to calculate the average intensity."],["Lamp Spectra","Sheet that depicts the lamp spectra, average wavelength, and peak wavelength."],["Irradiance Interpolation","Sheet that performs interpolation function in Excel to output spectral irradiance values for integer wavelengths so that values can be used in the Weighting tab."],["Photolyase Spect Interpolation","Sheet that performs interpolation function in Excel to output photolyase action spectra values for integer wavelengths so that values can be used in the Weighting tab."]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23]}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":25,"style":"italic"}],"key":"4c0ac","text":"In this spreadsheet, the E. coli photolyase action spectra is used as the weighting spectra. Using other microorganisms for photorepair will require obtaining action spectra for photolyase in that microorganism.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Gillian Payne, Aziz Sancar","can_edit":true,"date":642297600,"doi":"10.1021/bi00485a021","guid":"7F2A85E13D3F11EE88360A58A9FEAC02","journal":"Biochemistry","protocol_id":null,"title":"Absolute Action Spectrum of E-FADH2 and E-FADH2-MTHF Forms of Escherichia coli DNA Photolyase"}}}}

A summary of the contents of this spreadsheet is provided in Table 2 below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":125,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5f2m9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2idn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ctrh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"","id":397837,"original_name":"PhotorepairIrradiance.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nespbsif7.xlsx"}},"1":{"type":"tables","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"cellsMeta":{},"colTitles":["",""],"colWidths":["171","484"],"data":[["Sheet Name","Description"],["Plot","Shows a plot of all spectral irradiance measurements obtained at different distances from the light source"],["RawData","Contains all the raw measurements, including background measurements (i.e., dark controls with the cap on the spectroradiometer), and measurements taken at different distances"],["SpecIrr_BkgdCorrected","Spectral irradiance data with background corrections (i.e., background spectra subtracted from light spectra measurements)"],["Tabs named 12 to 12.35","Each tab has the data for measurements obtained at the various heights (units in cm). The sheets interpolate the measurements to integer wavelength values which can then be used in the Photorepair Fluence Calculation spreadsheet. The total irradiance from 320-475 nm is calculated in cell M2 as the sum of the spectral irradiance values between 320-475 nm."]],"guid":"A6E889503D4111EEA5EEFBD4CF947B93","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7lk5a","text":"Table 2. The sheets interpolate the measurements to integer wavelength values which can then be used in the Photorepair Fluence Calculation spreadsheet. title: Photorepair Fluence Response Protocol
warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"4vn3b","text":"UV exposure risk! Follow safety precautions for working with UV light sources. Wear PPE such as nitrile gloves, face shield, goggles, and lab coat. Put up signage to warn other lab personnel of potential UV light exposure. Work in biosafety cabinets according to the safety levels required for the microorganisms to be used in experiments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
